Question: 23 children were riding on the bus. At the bus stop 24 children got on the bus while some got off the bus. Then there were 8 children altogether on the bus. How many more children got off the bus than those that got on?
Thought:
import math 
import numpy as np 
# according to the questions, we can define the variables:
children_on_bus_before = 23
children_on_bus_after = 8
children_on_and_off_the_bus = 24
# Are follow up questions needed here:Yes.
# Follow up: how many children got off the bus?
children_off_the_bus = children_on_bus_before + children_on_and_off_the_bus - children_on_bus_after
# Follow up: how many more children got off the bus than those that got on?
children_got_off_the_bus = children_off_the_bus - children_on_and_off_the_bus
ans = children_got_off_the_bus

Question: Jake has 6 fewer peaches and 8 more apples than Steven. Steven has 17 peaches and 16 apples. How many more peaches than apples does Steven have?
Thought:
import math 
import numpy as np 
# according to the questions, we can define the variables:
steven_peaches = 17
steven_apples = 16
# Are follow up questions needed here:Yes.
# Follow up: how many peaches Jake have?
jake_peaches = steven_peaches - 6
# Follow up: how many apples Jake have?
jake_apples = steven_apples +8
# Follow up: How many more peaches than apples does Steven have?
ans= steven_peaches - steven_apples

Question: Paul got a box of 589 crayons for his birthday. During the school year he gave 571 crayons to his friends while he lost 161 crayons. How many more crayons did he give to his friends than those he lost?
Thought:
import math 
import numpy as np
# according to the questions, we can define the variables:
given_crayons = 571
lost_crayons = 161
# Are follow up questions needed here:No.
ans = given_crayons- lost_crayons

Question: Baker made 13 cakes. He sold 91 of them and bought 154 new cakes. How many more cakes did baker buy than those he sold?

import math 
import numpy as np

sold_cakes = 91
bought_cakes = 154
# Are follow up questions needed here:No.
Ans = bought_cakes - sold_cakes

Question: Rachel had to complete 4 pages of reading homework, 7 pages of math homework and 19 more pages of biology homework. How many more pages of math homework than reading homework did she have?

import math 
import numpy as np
# according to the questions, we can define the variables:
biology_homework = 19
reading_homework = 4
math_homework = 7
# Are follow up questions needed here:No.
Ans = math_homework-reading_homework

Question: He then went to see the oranges being harvested. He found out that they harvest 66 sacks per day and that each sack containes 25 oranges. How many oranges will they have after 87 days of harvest?
Thought:
import math 
import numpy as np
# according to the questions, we can define the variables:
harvest_sacks_per_day = 66
number_oranges_per_sack = 25
days_of_harvest = 87
# Are follow up questions needed here:Yes.
# Follow up:how many oranges will they harvest per day?
harvest_oranges_per_day = harvest_sacks_per_day*number_oranges_per_sack
# Follow up:How many oranges will they have after 87 days of harvest?
ans = days_of_harvest*harvest_oranges_per_day

Question: Last week Fred had 60 dollars and Jason had 19 dollars. Jason washed cars over the weekend and now has 33 dollars. How much money did Jason make washing cars?

import numpy as np

Dollar_fred_last_week = 60
Dollar_jason_last_week = 19
Dollar_jason_over_week  = 33
# Are follow up questions needed here:No.
ans = Dollar_jason_over_week - Dollar_jason_last_week

Question: There were 7 roses in the vase. Jessica cut some more roses from her flower garden which had a total of 59 roses. There are now 20 roses in the vase. How many roses did she cut?
